column4:
The quintessential Christmas spice, cloves add a powerful and intense aroma to cocktails and recipes of all descriptions.

These Single-Varietal bitters are made using only three ingredients; the spirit (High-proof Dark Rum) and Cloves with natural bittering agents.

Used sparingly, these bitters will add depth and intensity to most whisky cocktails, and are especially good in an old-fashioned made with high quality Bourbon, where the Whiskey is really required to shine through.

Coffee has become a Saturday morning tradition for Kendall and me.  Before we walk to the market we meet at the best coffee shop in our neighborhood, Contraband, and pick up a couple Cappuccinos to go. Nice, strong espresso with a perfect pillow of frothed milk. They’re heavenly. We don’t drink them every Saturday to make us more alert or to get us energized. Although the caffeine is a positive side effect of the beverage, we drink coffee for the ritual and taste.  We drink our coffee slowly, enjoying each sip—this is how I believe a cocktail should be enjoyed as well.
 

For our second batch of bitters, we decided to go with coffee. Coffee is relaxing, it smells good, it tastes good, and it brings people together… who doesn’t love it? A few dashes of Coffee Bitters in a whisky or rum cocktail just sounds like a recipe for happiness. The Coffee-Pecan Bitters recipe in Brad T. Parsons’ Bitters book inspires the recipe for my Coffee Bitters. If you’re thinking about making your own bitters, or just want to learn some cool facts about bitters, I highly suggest reading it.
 

IMG_2699.jpg
To make my Coffee Bitters, we combined ½ cup cracked coffee beans, 4 cracked cacao beans, ¼ teaspoon of black peppercorns, ½ teaspoon cassia chips, ½ teaspoon wild cherry bark, and 2 star anise in a quart-sized mason jar. For the coffee beans, don’t skimp on the quality. If you use crappy ingredients, you’re going to have crappy bitters. We used Contraband’s Yemen coffee, which is a medium roast with a sweet and earthy flavor—great stuff. We then drowned the coffee-bark-spice mixture in 2 cups of Wild Turkey 101 (the combination of the bourbon and coffee smells INCREDIBLE, by the way) and kept the jar at room temperature for 2 weeks, shaking the jar once a day.
IMG_2742_2.JPG
After the 2 weeks were up, we strained the liquid through cheesecloth to remove the solids, and then let the solids simmer in a saucepan with 1 cup of water for about 10 minutes. After it cooled, we put the contents of the saucepan in a separate mason jar and let it sit for another week, giving the jar a shake once a day. 

IMG_3027.jpg
IMG_3039.jpg
After waiting for another week, we strained out the solids and added the liquid to the other mason jar, which contained the original bourbon solution, along with 2 tablespoons of molasses. Three more days of waiting, one more run through cheesecloth, and finally, they’re done!

For the past three centuries, Cognac has been almost universally recognised as the finest of all the spirits that are distilled from grapes. It has many incomparable qualities: fruitiness, subtlety of bouquet, intensity, warmth and, above all, the complexity of the many thousands of styles and flavours from a (predominantly) single grape variety.

A small batch Anejo named after founder Don Julio Gonzalez-Frausto Estrada, who first distilled Tequila at the age of just 17 in 1942. Aged for at least 30 months in American white-oak, this is a remarkably smooth and incredibly complex Tequila with notes of tropical fruit, agave and a hint of cinnamon spice.

column4:
Chambord Liqueur (pronounced [ʃɑ̃.bɔʁ]) is a 16.5% abv raspberry liqueur modelled after a liqueur produced in the Loire Valley of France during the late 17th century. The Chambord product brand has been owned and produced by the Brown-Forman Corporation since 2006.[1]

Chambord is made from red and black raspberries, Madagascar vanilla, Moroccan citrus peel, honey and cognac.


Contents
1	History
2	Production
3	Bottle
4	Cocktails
5	Awards
6	References
7	External links
History
The Chambord brand was founded in 1982.[2] The drink was inspired by raspberry liqueur made in the Loire Valley in the late 1600s,[2] said to have been introduced to Louis XIV during one of his visits to the château de Chambord. It was common during that time for liqueurs and cognac to be consumed with elegant meals.

In 2006, the Chambord product brand was acquired by the Brown-Forman Corporation.[1]

Production
Chambord is produced in the Loire Valley from red and black raspberries, Madagascar vanilla, Moroccan citrus peel, honey and cognac. Whole raspberries and blackberries are steeped in French spirits for a period of several weeks to produce a fruit infusion.

After the infusion is extracted, a second set of spirits is added to the fruit and allowed to rest for a few weeks. After this second infusion is drawn off, the remaining fruit is pressed to obtain the natural sugars and juice. The fruit-infused spirits and juices from the final pressing are then combined, and finally, the berry infusion is married with a proprietary blend of cognac, natural vanilla extract, black raspberries, citrus peel, honey, and herbs and spices. The liqueur is 16.5% alcohol by volume.

Bottle
Chambord comes in a spherical bottle. Until mid-2010, the bottle came with a metallic gold plastic lettered 'belt' around the middle, and a crown atop its lid. The bottle was modeled after a globus cruciger.

In the U.S. market, the manufacturer began using a different bottle design in summer 2010, with modifications to the belt, lid and other elements.[3]

In addition to redesigning the bottle for the traditional Chambord liqueur, the manufacturer has also begun using the Chambord brand name on a flavoured vodka.[3]

Cocktails
Common drinks made from Chambord include the Raspberry Margarita, French Manhattan, Rolling Green (cocktail)[vodka,lemonade] Butler Miller (Chambord Vodka Gimlet),[4] Kir Impérial (Chambord and champagne), Chambord Daiquiri, Chambord Royal Spritzer, Lemonado (Vodka, lemonade and splash of Chambord), Little Purple Men, The Purple Hooter Shooter, Sour Grapes, Black Opal, Peanut Butter and Jelly (with Frangelico or Castries Peanut Cream), Grape Crush, the "Blood of Christ", Grateful Dead, and the French Martini. The French Martini started the "cocktails as a Martini" craze.[5]

This superbly crisp, aromatic cucumber-flavoured gin was launched by Gordon's in 2013. It is based on Gordon's classic London Dry Gin and is flavoured naturally with cucumber. The result is something akin to Hendrick's gin, and it works very well in Gin and Tonics!

column4:
Almost 250 years ago, Alexander Gordon started his distillery in London and set about creating the recipe for a brilliant tasting gin. Gordon's high quality and distinctive juniper flavour has come to define the taste of the classic G&T. 

Gordon's today is a gin that's enjoyed, not dissected. It's the perfect gin to start a Friday evening, or a Tuesday night catch up with friends, where we share a moment and have a laugh with people we love.

column4: Guinness (/ˈɡɪnɪs/) is a dark Irish dry stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in 1759. It is one of the most successful beer brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. [1][2] Sales in 2011 amounted to 850 million litres (220,000,000 US gal).[1] It is popular with the Irish, both in Ireland and abroad. In spite of declining consumption since 2001,[3] it is still the best-selling alcoholic drink in Ireland.[4][5] where Guinness & Co. Brewery makes almost €2 billion worth annually.
column5:
Date: Gotta love illegible date codes, I think this is a late 2018 can, consumed on 03/28/19.

Appearance: Pours out like a coke, then puts on a beautiful cascading act in the glass. Once this is finished, it takes on the traditional stout look with ruby color around the bottom. Guinness produces over two fingers of what has to be the most creamy sand colored head that a beer ever produced.

Aroma: Roasted malts, light coffee, and chocolate are all on the nose with the malts actually seeming to have so depth to them. No one aspect is very pronounced, but it smell nice.

Taste: Here is where we have some issues. First, Guinness is terribly thin, not a whole lot more substantial than water. The taste, while presenting a pleasant dry roasted bitter malt profile, never really amounts to much else. Yes, there is some chocolate and a mild coffee flavors, but this is a beer seems fearful of being what it should be. The widget in the can does give it a ridiculously creamy texture though. To sum Guinness up, it has been nice to revisit and old staple, but it simply cannot stand up to its craft brethren such as Deschutes Black Butte Porter. This St. Patrick's Day leftover reminds my why I only buy this once a year.

Poured from a 

Look: Pours a beautiful dark brown, almost black color. Rich and creamy with an absolutely perfect, creamy, white-tan head.
Smell: Aroma of bittersweet cocoa, Some roasted grain malt in the background underneath. Some bitterness.
Taste: Flavor of milk chocolate, roasted grain malt and even some dark coffee in the background. Encompasses the full flavor profile of a stout.
Feel: Oh sooo smooth. Milky. Creamy. Goes down like chocolate milk. It is no wonder the Irish picked this as their staple beer.

Overall: When you want a light beer and are considering any of American macrolagers, stop yourself and ask yourself rather whether you want a Guinness. This beer incorporates chocolate, roasted grain malts, and even coffee into a drinkable Irish stout that is so smooth, you'll ask yourself why you don't live in Ireland. It defines the light beer version of a stout. So well done and a tradition, you can't go wrong with a Guinness.

I started drinking Guinness in an Irish bed and breakfast, served to me by a lovely Irish lass just after St. Patrick's Day in 1998. Since then I have had a few every March in celebration. It used to be my gold standard for a stout, and is still good, but lacks some of the character of others with coffee and/or chocolate notes. The beer pours a wonderful dark black and I love watching the bubbles go down the side of the glass. It is not as bitter as I remember, probably due to changing tastes on my part, and has a smooth creamy taste that lingers on the tongue. Overall I quite like it, but not near enough to have an exclusive relationship with it.

Poured from a 

Look: Pours a beautiful dark brown, almost black color. Rich and creamy with an absolutely perfect, creamy, white-tan head.
Smell: Aroma of bittersweet cocoa, Some roasted grain malt in the background underneath. Some bitterness.
Taste: Flavor of milk chocolate, roasted grain malt and even some dark coffee in the background. Encompasses the full flavor profile of a stout.
Feel: Oh sooo smooth. Milky. Creamy. Goes down like chocolate milk. It is no wonder the Irish picked this as their staple beer.

Overall: When you want a light beer and are considering any of American macrolagers, stop yourself and ask yourself rather whether you want a Guinness. This beer incorporates chocolate, roasted grain malts, and even coffee into a drinkable Irish stout that is so smooth, you'll ask yourself why you don't live in Ireland. It defines the light beer version of a stout. So well done and a tradition, you can't go wrong with a Guinness.

I started drinking Guinness in an Irish bed and breakfast, served to me by a lovely Irish lass just after St. Patrick's Day in 1998. Since then I have had a few every March in celebration. It used to be my gold standard for a stout, and is still good, but lacks some of the character of others with coffee and/or chocolate notes. The beer pours a wonderful dark black and I love watching the bubbles go down the side of the glass. It is not as bitter as I remember, probably due to changing tastes on my part, and has a smooth creamy taste that lingers on the tongue. Overall I quite like it, but not near enough to have an exclusive relationship with it.

From a nitro can. Black in color. Poured with a moderate, creamy, almond white foam with excellent retention. Dark malt and light roasted malt aromas. Medium light bodied with a light creamy feel. Dark malt flavors up front that slowly turn roasty. Roasted flavor expands through the middle introducing bitter roasted flavors and charred malt near the end. Finished dryly with lingering bitter, charred malt flavors that slowly fade. Great look and pleasant aromas. Feel is generally thin and the charred malt flavors hurt the drinkability. Their foreign export stout is far better.

column4: David Beckham has made his mark in the world of whisky with the launch of Haig Club. A light and sweet grain whisky, Haig Club is aimed at drinkers who have yet to be won over by whisky’s charms. Named after John Haig, the founder of Cameronbridge distillery (where the whisky is made), Haig Club is superb over ice, in long drinks or in short cocktails – it’s an easy-drinking dram that will win anyone over. Nose: Toffee and bananas up front, with green grassy notes, and gentle ginger, nutmeg and cinnamon spiciness. Palate: Sweet and creamy to start, with soft caramel and toffee. Lemon peel zestiness develops, with tingly cinnamon. Creamy lemon posset with a crunchy bar? Finish: Spice, toffee, soft anise and a touch of warmth. Comment: Light and sweet with more complexity than you might expect. It's not a whisky that you'll be sitting down to examine over hours, but it does have good flavours, that are strong enough to shine through even when mixed.
column5: a gift which i’m afraid will end up in the bin. now i know why i always buy single malt whisky.really rather good. not to everyone’s taste clearly, but i enjoyed it.i can only describe this as bad. effective marketing made me buy this but other than that it doesn't offer much. not smooth, not enjoyable.very smooth. i love it.not at all pleasant, i'm not even sure this actually tastes like whisky at all. it has a very strange chemical flavour to it.i’m a fledgling whisky enthusiast and at first i tried to mentally justify the horrid taste of this whisky as it’s “character” and assumed that i was the one who couldn’t appreciate its qualities. well, with more experience under my belt i can say with confidence that this whiskey is horrid. it smells like acetone, has no real depth or flavour other than setting your mouth on fire with its harshness.can't stand single malt, but this went down very well.this whisky is awful. i'd steer clear of it unless you fancy blowing 40 quid on a drink to mix with soft drinks. very overpriced.it's reasonably smooth, and relatively easy to drink, but boy oh boy does it lack character. i'm relieved that it was a gift, as i now know never to exchange my own money for another bottle. i can see that there would obviously be an audience for this, but i personally prefer the complexity of many alternative single malts.this is the worst "scotch" i have ever tasted. i kept drinking it (it was a gift) out of respect for the person who gave it to me. i hoped my opinion of it would improve as i pushed on, but it didn't. smells like paint thinner. tastes like paint thinner. it is labeled as "single grain" and not "single malt". i'm not sure what that means, but in hindsight i think its a bad sign. it says it is "aged in toasted oak casks" but doesn't say for how long. another bad sign. if david beckham put his name on this, well then that guy has never drank scotch before.fabulous whisky. this has become my favourite of all. slight taste of vanilla.excellent taste with a fruity flavor.. enjoyed a good whiskey after a long timevery smooth indeed! characters are spot on.i want to add to my existing review - comparing this beverage to a single malt is like comparing a chevy chase film to 2001: a space odyssey. there is a world of difference between the two; but both can be good in their own rights. what i want to say is that it is not possible to exist on low-end fun or high-end philosophy alone - it turns one into a bore (hope i'm not!). this is why this drink is fine with me - but not all the time. variety is the spice of life, and it is not a single malt. but, instead it is a rather pleasant drink. don't take it too seriously, and enjoy it for what it is. by the way, i am a graphic designer, and knowing how this business works, i deliberately extracted the bottle design, the packaging, the branding and the endorsements from my mind before i drank this whisky from a clear glass with a clear mind.i'm drinking it right now as i type. first time i've tried it. i think the mistake is to compare it to it's illustrious relative, the single malt. i've not drank a single grain whisky before - plenty of single malts. comparing product a to product b seems to be a mistake. we all like what we like as personal favourites - yet without expanding our alcoholic experiences, life would be a jaded experience indeed. diversity in alcohol is indeed a wonderful concept. so, i'm giving haig club (regardless of beckham) a 5, because upon its own merits, it is smooth, makes me tipsy (baileys on steroids comes to mind) - and so what if it's for a younger market? i'm nearly 50, but our children are the future - celebrate them & drink with them! when i want something cerebral and deep, a single malt it will be... but this drink is great - on it's own merits. stop comparing two totally different drinks. its like comparing orange and purple - both can be great in the right context. so, lighten up when you want to be light and drink haig - and go down deep when you need to hit the source, and drink a single malt.really easy to knock next to a more complex whisky but it is super smooth, creamy and sweet which makes as a great first stepping stone. light and fits into the style of fresh tasting japanese whisky.very little other than alcohol on the nose, and the palate disappears in an instant. not even the alcohol that existed on the nose is there on the palate, it turns to little more than water in your mouth. it does have an excellent mouthfeel, but there's simply no reason to keep it on your tongue because there's no taste to it. some sweet notes arrive after you swallow, as does the alcohol, but it's far too little far too late. an utter joke of a whisky for the price they're asking, for a £35-45 whisky to be near-undrinkable without a mixer is unacceptable. you could buy a bottle of bell's for 1/3 of the price!horrible. smells like turps, tastes worse. none of the flavours i look for in a whiskey let alone a single malt scotch. if you can even call it that. glad i got it cheap cause if i paid full price i’d be pissed off.it is what it says it is - easy going, not very complex but smooth and likeable, nicely marketed without being very special - and too expensive david beckham is a very appropriate brand ambassador.very bland and disappointing whisky. would be great at £10-£15, but absolutely baffling at this price

column4: Inspired by an Italian, created in London and distilled in Scotland, J&B Rare is unlike any other Scotch whisky. It brings together 42 single malt and grain whiskies and carefully blends them to create a subtle, smooth and complex flavour. It’s this delicate balance that gives J&B Rare its distinctive character – if we took even one whisky away, you would taste the difference. At the heart of J&B Rare are malt whiskies from Speyside, a region recognised as the superior area in Scotland for making single malt whisky. They provide the fruity, fresh quality you can taste, and also give J&B its light colour. Added to that are some of the finest grain whiskies Scotland has to offer. They help reveal the individual flavours of the various malts, unveiling the smooth character of J&B Rare. Great in a cocktail, the unique blend makes it perfect for mixing – so by all means go overboard on the mixers, but please don’t go overboard on the J&B.
column5: poured in a glass and was put off by the lightness on the eyes. on the palate made up for anything i thought would be lacking.not sure why the the rave reviews. a little bit like white spirit: not enough aging and flavour. inoffensive though. 2.5 starsabsolutely stunning for the price. sweet, with a touch of smoke & peat, j&b has been a staple on my bar for years. without doubt it is one of the classic blends along with johnnie walker and ballantines. the only negative is the colour, i imagine the lightness puts some off, but it doesn’t bother me in the slightest! such a shame that this is rarely available in bars in the uk, we seem to prefer to serve lesser blended scotch, but when you travel around the world, this will feature in the selection of any bar worth it’s salt.what a tastemy grandmother has had this in her cabinet since i can remember. the yellow label is just one of those childhood memories (visually of course). until now! 39-years-old and a traveled chef who has tasted, sipped, enjoyed as well as simply guzzled my fair share of pleasant to rot-gut liquors. i finally tasted her j&b with quite the satisfied outcome. then i slowly poured myself two more! my conscience slapped me thinking maybe this is some high dollar hooch! pleasantly surprised to find that it isn't even close to the price of murray mcdavid or even macallan 18. fantastically smooth and rich, without me having to be personally! thumbs up all around.i'm satisfied.have been a j&b man a long time, as dean martin was. puts jw to shame. great taste, great price.i have it is a pleasant drink. it is not exactly rare considering how freely available it is?tried it on a plane and loved it. tasted like expensive, world-class whisky. so surprised to see it so cheap! definitely buying a bottle or two.one of the best scotch i have ever tasted...luv j&ban absolute classic, and much like johnnie walker black and ballantines, j&b is always a welcome friend wherever you find yourself in the world. predominately for the export market it seems, it’s a shame you don’t see it more often in pubs/bars here because in spain it is in every bar you walk into! i’ve always thought the light colour of j&b in the glass as not great on the eye, but don’t let that put you off. what you get is a nice sweet whiskey, with a hint of smoke and a pleasant fruitiness to it.bloody amazing.perfect for the priceundeniably a fantastic blend and a fantastic blend but if you like this you should give teachers a try it's cheaper and has more malty crunch! they're very similar in many ways.absolutely the cheapest scotch i will drink. perfect flavor for a blended. always enjoy on the rocks or with soda... no other way.j&an has been my choice for about 40 years. started with a lemon slice at first to cut taste. now just over rocks. love it. however not readily available in southern states and florida. usually have to drink dewars which is usually available. not really a fan of single malts. would get them as gifts and would give them away.from single malts to blended, for twenty years this stuff is my constant whiskey in the house. either over two cubes or with rochester ginger ale is how i enjoy it.i've been buying scotch lately in contrast to bourbon, got some johnny walker, red, black, double, and even some gold, they seemed ok, but put a hole in the pocket, wanted something affordable and picked up some j&b, boy was i surprised, you can taste the speysides and even a fruitiness i like, with even a wisp of smoke...after drinking johnny black this is a little better then the red to me and almost as good as the black if not equal due to the difference in blend and price!nice sweet whiskylove it, in rotation with jameson & bushmills. hugging 70 years young.

column4: With flavours of apple cider blended with lemon, spices and the goodness of root ginger, Jeremiah Weed Root Brew is a drink like no other, a celebration of Kentucky that’s making its mark around the world.
column5: It's a tasty brew, only stated at 4% but it's cider and Whisky based not vodka, so there's a kickIve had this before and enjoy it. its going out of production though i believe This is a really nice cider with a slight ginger taste . Highly recommended

column4: Produced and bottled in the UK, rather far from the brand’s marketing suggestion of USA’s Deep South, with a “Gentleman” and the “Sour Mash” term possibly cheekily hinting at another Southern gentleman. Made with fruit alcohol (16.5%), Bourbon (4.9%) and flavourings. Appearance Deep coppery amber bordering on ale brown with virtually no head. Aroma Burnt blackened fruit cake with caramel, maple charcoal, roasted macadamia nuts and bourbon. Taste Dilute subdued flavours of buttery toffee popcorn, caramel and pecan pie nuttiness. Very bourbon and coke with a lemon slice made dilute and slightly flat by being left in a glass with ice. Aftertaste Burnt toffee/caramel and maple syrup.
column5: Highly ginger aroma. Looks like ginger beer. Tastes like ginger beer. Nice bottle. Very drinkable. Doesn't leave a nasty taste.

column4: ohnnie Walker Black Label is a true icon, recognized as the benchmark for all other deluxe blends. Created using only whiskies aged for a minimum of 12 years from the four corners of Scotland, Johnnie Walker Black Label has an unmistakably smooth, deep character. An impressive whisky to share on any occasion, whether you're entertaining at home or on a night out with friend NOSE Take in the luxurious scent of rich and tropical dark fruits with hints of sweet vanilla. PALATE Savor the depth of flavor developed from maturation in oak casks, combined with creamy toffee notes that come from grain whiskies. FINISH This iconic whisky delivers a smooth and warming smoke finish, characteristic of all Johnnie Walker whiskies.
column5: a great daily dram. very competent, and immensely superior to red.now we're talking! full bodied, smoky, dried fruits and some sweet notes. very well made. a classic.safe and dull. it's very smooth, and has a pleasant silky mouth feel, but i'm finding it very one dimensional, and frankly, boring. just not enough going on for me.black label is a very solid, consistent whisky. nothing about this is overpowering, but nothing is boring or disappointing, either. its always good, every single time. great for new whisky drinkers and those with seasoned tongues alike.i love it, maybe too much.not smooth enough, it sticks to the back of your throat and feels as though it can’t decide what it wants to be.i have to agree with daniel and t-bone on this one, this is not a great whisky. if you're looking for readily available smooth-drinking scotch, i'd also recommend glenlivet 12.fine scotchsmooth and a little smoky and sweet at the same time.a delicious mix of some of the finest malts, creating a wonderful tipple that agrees with my rather fussy tongue. i first received a bottle of black label as a gift from my partner ryan to celebrate our first christmas together and it had become one of my favourite drams. i prefer this to the blue or red labels. splendid drop.i have died and gone to heaven, this is the smoothest whisky that i have ever tasted. i will use black label from now on.one of my favourites. class in a glass.better than what i was expecting. better than most whiskies at this, or a similar price. could be a bit smokier, but not bad. excellent body and finish. try it out if you haven't already.i love it!! after a good square meal i have jwbl and it is awesome.most memorable drink i had in my lifeit's a good whiskey with a fair price. the taste is of smoke and creamy toffee. the aftertaste is sweet enough! good choice!this is a great blended scotch. i have no idea how they go from red lable to this but they are totally different. i generally choose laphroaig or ardbeg but if those are not available i can always count on black lable.frankly, i liked red label more than black. somehow it lacks the peaty tones for me. it's silky, more "rounded" on the tongue with a hint of raisins...good feelinggood smoky blend. not overpowering and leaves a nice aftertaste. jwdb is better though!

column1: johnnie walker® black label® blended scotch whisky
column4: Johnnie Walker Black Label's iconic square bottle makes it one of the world's most recognisable Scotch whiskies - and it's also one of whisky critic Jim Murray's favourite blends: 'If there is a silkier delivery on the market today, I have not seen it: this is sublime stuff...one of the world's most masterful whiskies back in all its complex glory' PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES Nose: Rich dried fruits from the European oak sherry casks. Palate: Hints of smooth creamy toffee linger on the tip of your tongue. Finish: A sophisticated, smoky finish - the signature of all Johnnie Walker blends.

column1: johnnie walker® blue label® blended scotch whisky
column4: Johnnie Walker's most prestigious whisky. Probably THE most famous super-premium blend, made up of the finest old-aged malt and grain whiskies. The Cristal of the blended whisky world. Blue Label’s bold, multi-layered palate and silky delivery ensure that it sits unchallenged at the top of the Johnnie Walker pile.PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES Nose: A mellow, rounded nose, with a dry smokiness (a Johnnie Walker signature flavour) mixed with raisin sweetness. Palate: The first sip reveals a velvety mouthfeel, then an explosion of flavour – hazelnuts, honey, rose petals, sherry and oranges. Subsequent sips reward you with more hidden secrets like kumquats, wispy aromatic smoke, sandalwood, tobacco, and dark chocolate. Finish: A rich and uniquely long and satisfying finish of smoke and pepper, ending with a glorious touch of spice.
column5: bought this engraved as an anniversary present for my husband. i couldn't contain my excitement, so i gave it to him early – he absolutely loved it. shipping was much faster than expected as well. i will definitely be buying from here again.i bought this with an engraving as a birthday present for my fiancé – he was overjoyed! the customer service was really helpful throughout, delivery made within a day and bottle was beautifully packed.perhaps the best way to judge blue is to have a tasting of six or seven blended whiskies, rating them as you go along. in my experience, blue always emerges as the most accomplished blend by quite a lot. it's expensive, and there are some cheaper single malts i'd choose for a daily dram, but this is a scotch to know about and taste at least once.my favourite whisky of all time. forget about price, this is the one i want to drink. the only whisky that has ever come close was six-times the price of blue label - makes blue label very drinkable everyday.didn't try it. it was a present with engraving for my husband. he didn't open it yet. but he's super happy. a bit expensive but worth it. don't like your delivery provider but there is nothing i can do, but at least arrived on his birthday.a shadow of its former self. astonishing that they ask full price for what is now a very sub-par grain heavy blend. johnny walker brands now seeking new depths to plumb.one of my favorites. worth every dime. i drive 50 minutes to the only location that sells this near me.over priced? yes. over rated? probably. spectacular? yup! very smooth, delightfully complex, and all of the flavor i’m looking for.nose was very weak. palate was somewhat interesting and "smooth" with quinine and pears but too light. i have tried two whiskies in my life that can deliver at 40% but this is not one. if this cost 40 quid i would give it 4 stars but at the actual price its 2 stars. if you're a whisky fan this is not for you, there much better options.at 40 percent this is a total rip offamazing!some years ago someone gave me a bottle of blue label as a gift and it was one of the most wonderful whiskies i have ever tasted – smooth and tender, so it was my dream to buy it one day. ten days ago i have bought it, but this time it was pure dissapointment. i can not believe how big is the difference. i bought it in slovenia...great a must try for alla very good whisky - very smooth. not worth the price. black label is a much better purchase.i bought a bottle last christmas, it has always been a dream of mine to get this whisky as a am a frequent drinker of the red label and black label products. blue label however was a whisky like no other and it's hard to explain just how good it is. lets just say it's by far one of the best whiskies the world has to offer, and you will just have to buy it to see for yourself. i will surely be ordering getting another bottle for christmas as well as the new game of thrones inspired white walker whisky. the fact is johnnie walker make the best whiskies and even their cheapest red label is a decent bottle of scotch.great service!bought this as a 30th birthday present for my friend. absolutely fantastic. better than expected! the bottle and case looked stunning and the engraving was a lovely touch. he was over the moon!very fast deliverya nice experiencebought this as a leaving present for one of the podiatric consultants. very very pleased with the engraving and the packaging and i know he loved it... i have had johnnie walker blue before – would recommend the site.

column1: johnnie walker® double black label® blended scotch whisky
column4: An interesting twist on Johnnie Walker Black Label, Double Black was rolled out for general release in 2011 after a successful launch in travel retail. Double Black adds to the normal Black Label profile by including more Islay whisky and casks that have been heavily charred, giving a more intense flavour with a greater emphasis on smoke while keeping true to the sophisticated Johnnie Walker style. PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES Palate: The flavour is full bodied and complex with the signature Johnnie Walker peat smoke shining brightly through rich raisins and sultanas. Apples, pears and orange zest bring freshness while creamy vanilla and spice bring a softness and sweetness to the tongue. Finish: The long warming finish combines spicy oak tannins and lingering smoke.
column5: this must be what the gods drinkdoesn’t quite have the signature black label fire, really it's more smoke than flame, so lacking something. however, for folks who like it smoother and sweeter than the usual it’s a nice dram.superbought for my brother as a christmas present. he liked it and was thrilled with the personalised label. the bottle arrived next day or the day after if i am not mistaken – as usual, the deliveries are always quicker then expected. well done.the idea of a double black is clever and could have been brilliant if they had just stuck to the 12 year old formula with additional caol ila and talisker bottled at 46%. but this offering is all about charred oak using some young and uninteresting basic whiskies. clearly a much cheaper to produce alternative. not good enough diageo!horrible nosing, awful palate - so thin. just a hand full of smoke! avoid.very strong smell and unpleasant lingering taste. i will stick to normal black or red i will never buy this againif this was a car, it'd be a 1984 2.8i ford granada. brutally designed and takes skill, experience and respect to master and enjoy. love it to bits.my first sip tasted like the inside of an ashtray. after that it improved as i got used to the shock of the tar. it's nice and smooth. i like it.great.really smooth. strong smoke smell. my go to scotch.very enjoyable so far from a rookie scotch drinker. however very similar to johnnie walker black.highly charred casks produces wood smoke galore. cloying sweetness is unpleasant and there is little else in the flavour department.bought for the first time. very good. very smooth. enjoyed more than the higher priced single malts. will definitely be buying again.bought as a 50th birthday gift for my brother. delighted with personalised label and delivery very quick. will definitely use the whisky exchange again.i think this is a quite fabulous blended scotch. finished off my first bottle in such a short time that my girlfriend was almost getting a tad concerned. highly underrated. yes, there are likely some young whiskies in here, but the intensity is a very pleasant one, as is the sweetness and smokiness (which is not overdone at all imo). perhaps not as easy to drink as the regular black (and in fact so different from it that the two really don't have much to do with each other), but i could drink this all day (if that wasn't a fairly bad idea, of course). have only tried it neat so far, and but i will try it with a few drops of water (don't see the point in adding ice here). i really can't think of a better blend for the money, and i also prefer this to many single malts that cost more. i did not expect that at all - in fact my expectations were fairly low. two thumbs up. one of my favourites.simply superba very solid blended scotch, warming and smokey with complexity if you're willing to look for it. citrus and apple are there along with honey and raisins. the finish is darker taking me back to bonfires with treacle toffee. overall a wonderfully drinkable whisky and one i'm sure i will purchase againvery smooth and smokey flavour – love it.was my fav blend until i had green label! jwdb is a fantastic whisky though and more flavour than black label. it's a bridge between the more pungent and powerful islay monsters (which i love).

column4: Johnnie Walker Gold Label was relaunched in 2012. Built around a core of single malt whisky from Clynelish, the Gold Label Reserve is a great addition to the line-up from master blender Jim Beveridge. PRODUCER'S NOTES Nose: Honey, vanilla cream, sherry-style dried fruits and notes of biscuits. Palate: Luxuriously smooth, creamy and delicately honeyed with lingering waves of wood, fruit and light, sweet smoke. A multi-layered blend of sweet fruits and creaminess that evokes deeper honey tones. Finish: Lingering waves of wood and light west-coast smoke.
column5: thin and watery - definitely not my favourite. lacks character.very smooth.this is such a good scotch. very creamy, smooth, sweet honey. lots of vanilla and fruit.beautiful. a jw platinum fan myself, but this is very smooth with a great bouquet. highly recommend.money, so smooth! this has all the flavors i’m looking for, sweet done right! price point is still high, i’ll take glenlivet 15 over this for less $.very smooth to be sipped slowlya very nice whiskey and my personal label just makes it perfect.personalized bottle looks very good and not a bad price but to bring it to australia it cost me just under $200aud :/it's for my son's 40th. his favourite and i love the label.perfect service!!smooth and another nice johnnie walkeri know the product and it is lovely, hovewer i would like to mention that i got a great customer support from adrian who was extremely helpful with solving some issues. i rate him very highly.best of the walkers. if i had to recommend an elegant and delicate whisky this would be it.good quality blend, slight after taste but overall nice drop.i love this gold reserve, really liked the double black but this tops it. tried it with my best friend and he loves it too! really a fantastic whisky lovely and smooth.black was my favourite,after gold, i see and taste the different note and black is now relegated to second place.simply amazing. fast delivery and very well packed. a gift that will be much appreciatedthis is the perfect whisky for mixing amazing cocktails, the caramel popcorn notes go great with maple syrup and a pinch of butter and salt.my best freind is jw gold label reserve, great testei really like the gold reserve but its ruined my taste for jw black label and similar whiskies like chivas. its much smoother, refined and delicious on the rocks.

column1: johnnie walker® platinum blended scotch whisky
column4: Johnnie Walker Platinum Label 18 Year Old blends big, classic Johnnie Walker flavours with intriguing contemporary notes of citrus and fragrant almonds. Initially sweet with a warm vanilla undercurrent and a suggestion of tangerines, it moves smoothly over the palate into a nutty, malty dryness before a long finish brings elegant suggestions of soft charcoal smokiness and a beautifully fading citrus zest.
column5: Very smooth with well balance sweetness and long finish, I had the gold explorer ,a dalmore king alexander and the platinum and everybody keep drinking this one . Received this as a holiday gift. It is so good we are afraid to drink it. We found ourselves stranded in a hotel room a 3:00 a.m. due to bad weather and felt it was the perfect time to treat ourselves. Savored 1 finger of this precious liquid for bout 45 minutes and must say it is the best scotch we have ever tasted. So smooth and really delicious. We will buy another bottle before this amazing scotch is no longer available. Where the Blue falls flat in flavor, the Platinum keeps pushing forward in a delightful way. The Platinum is not quite as smooth as the Blue - which is so smooth as to be almost boring - but the Platinum has a buttery texture on the taste buds on the sides and back of your tongue that none of the other Walkers have. I was sad when the complex and sweet Gold 18 year went away. Now I do not care. Platinum is the best Walker out there. Tasting notes: I prefer Blue and Platinum neat. Gold with one tiny ice cube.

column1: johnnie walker® red label® blended scotch whisky
column4: Johnnie Walker Red Label was launched in its current form by brothers George and Alexander Walker in 1909, though it had existed as Walker's Special Old Highland Red Label for some years previously. Alexander blended a type of whisky which is more suited to mixing with soda than the heavier, more old-fashioned whiskies, and named it after his grandfather, who had started the family business in 1820. Today it is the world's most popular whisky and is sold in more than 200 markets world-wide. PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES Nose: Hints of fresh apple, pear and the spark of zest from the elegant Speyside malts. Palate: Fruity sweetness, cinnamon and pepper crackling on the centre of your tongue. Finish: A sophisticated, smoky finish - the signature of all Johnnie Walker blends.
column5: good whisky – smoky and a little peaty. good for everyday drinksharsh and unpleasant. for the money, the famous grouse is far superior. so is dewars. probably okay for mixed drinks, but who wants a mixed drink with scotch?this is a bit too smoky for my taste, but if that’s your thing you’ll probably like this.this is a good blended scotch. only malt snobs hate it.sweeter than i expected. smokey and a little peaty. i like it.i tried it in bulgaria golden sands last year. it's taste was great and i will never forget it!this stuff is horrible. it tastes so bad, like smoked, burnt grass. i would not recommend it.jw red label is one of my favourites. as i said in other reviews, i tasted a few entry level blended scoth whisky's side by side, older and new one's, and for me, generally, they are fall down in quality. my style of scotch is that smokey like this one or passport scotch, black&white, black bottle or william lawson's. no doubt that jw black label is a good scotch, once it's my reference when i think in scotch, but it's only a bit deep than red. jw red label is very similar and not so smooth. the smoothness sometimes can be bored, and jw red label is bit more explosive with well integrated smoky and malt. i like very much the smell of this whisky.it's the best whiskyi used to think this was not good. i came back to it and really like it. neat. really like it.i bought a bottle of this. this was horrible. it tasted like something foreign was added. i tried to complain about this on their web site in the "contact" page, but the form is buggy and would not let me submit the form with the complaint. i wouldn't recommend this stuff to anyonered label: you can't compare this with the others in the jw stable, would be unfair. would be a good introduction for anyone not too sure about smoke as it come through faintly. that said, for the price it's a fantastic daily driver, which is what i use it for.for the price, this is an excellent scotch. my go-to jw is green label, but i like this now and then. it also mixes well and makes a nice rob roy, if you are into cocktails. i also keep three or four single malts in my bar. as for some of the comments about american whiskey, i can't figure it out. we have some nice whiskeys and bourbons here that stand up well to various whiskeys made around the world. jim beam black, maker's 46, knob creek, weller's and buffalo trace, among others, make some excellent whiskeys and bourbons, as do the canadians. i prefer scotch, but i keep plenty of the other whiskeys around for my guests who have a different preference. i give red a four star rating because we are comparing it to others in its price range, like dewar's white label, which is ok, also. if you compare it to the higher end jw's and single malts, you are doing it a disservice.not a bad scotch but j&b and famous grouse is much, much better as far as your basic scotch goes.seriously do not understand how some people say this is trash.. this is a damn good dram! wow man.. i have to say this is the best cheap whisky i've ever had! personally i wouldn't mix it with anything. it's good the way it is but to each their own make it the way you like. completely love that signature johnnie taste. my mind is blown i was expecting this to be bad because of what other people were saying... it's not. it's a good, solid bargain whisky to have on your bar. period.it's strongit tastes like the put gasoline in a bottle of whiskey and sold it. very disappointed as i am a fan of walker's drinksenjoying now, perhaps better than black label imo, as someone else below said soft...but with a smoky palate with toffee/buttery and citrus. lovelyi find it much better than any other scotch of the similar value. even i prefer than 12 yrs old including black level.excellent taste , smokey finish

column4: Ketel One Citroen flavored vodka begins with Ketel One Vodka, infused with the essence of four different types of citrus lemons, and two types of limes to enhance the freshness. Fragrance. Taking in Ketel One Citroen’s aroma, you'll notice a refreshingly sweet lemon zest fragrance. Flavor. Taste the hints of freshly cut lemon and delicate honey sweetness. Feel. The feel is pleasant, with a silky softness on the palate. Finish. A sweet honey and lemony custard aftertaste lingers gently, followed by a long finish.
column5: Smoothest taste especially when its on sale This is a great vodka ! Eask to drink just over ice.....enjoy

column4: Using carefully selected European wheat and a combination of modern and traditional distilling techniques, we produce an exceptional product, both crisp to taste and soft on finish. Here, the 4Fs – Fragrance, Flavour, Feel and Finish – help to define what makes Ketel One Vodka so unique. Fragrance. Nosing the aroma of Ketel One, you’ll immediately detect freshness with hints of citrus and honey. Flavour. Savour the crisp, lively tingle. Feel. Let the signature silky softness coat your tongue. Finish. A long finish with subtle flavours reminds you of its quality.
column5: excellenti'm quite the wuss when it comes to liqour, but this is one i do well with. very smooth and drinkableamazingly smooth only way to drink is on rocks??excellent. best on the rocks.very very good. this is an alternative vodka, it isn't trying to be high end, it's just plainly it's own. amazing for contemporary martini's and cheap enough to be your standard at home or in the drawer at work!goes fastvery smooth and tasty vodka one of the few remaining pot stilled vodkas available in my opinion much better than grey goose and very close to the greatness of belvedere

column4: The Islay representative in the 'Classic Malts' series is a deep, dry and exceptionally peaty bruiser. Probably the most pungent of all Islay malts, Lagavulin is not for the faint-hearted but inspires fanatical devotion in its many followers.
column5: this is quite remarkable. i recently purchased a bottle to try after much deliberation, as i'm not big on peaty malts. however, the lapsang souchong smokiness works wonderfully with the sweetness, which i actually prefer over the aforementioned tea. i'd certainly buy this bottle againmagic in a glassgreatest scotch in my book!a remarkable scotch with exquisite smoky, peaty nuances that tingle on the tongue with strong lingering flavours on the finish. not for the faint of heart.smoke and iodine nose, with a wonderful briny palate. awesome stuff.the single worst, most peat-mossy scotch i ever wasted my money on. the peat definitely does move in a weird direction on this on – not at all what i expected. like a good smooth scotch, but not this one. unfortunately not even worthy as a mixer.i was blown away by this scotch. smooth, smoky and perfectly balanced.one of my all time favorite tipples, love the smoky peatiness of it.outstanding whisky, but maybe not for casual scotch drinkers.great whiskey!wowzers! my new favourite by far: fire and brimstone, a pyromaniacs dream... i'd give it 6* - off the scale!!definitely worth the price. perfect smoky and a good taste of tobacco but a little bit too dry for my taste. it gets better and better the more you drink.smooth with the right amount of peat for us islay fanatics. complex and finishes with a touch of sweetness . great bottle.i’m completely smitten by this islay that has so much character. i have multiple bottles of famous scotches which come in fancy bottles and gold crested labels and other embellishments, that are simply ignored. i find myself reaching for the unpretentious bottle every time i open the drinks cabinet. lovely.it's absolutely unique. i love it. you can feel the rough scottish climate cold and windy. wind, sea waves, rocks and fireplaces smoke. best single malt i've ever drank. correction: the best period.simply the best.this is only the 3rd single malt added to my new founded collection. it is also my 1st islay. i chose this one based on the amount of good reviews it has. nose - smoke, iodine, brine, seaweed, rope, spices. palate - smoke, brine, kippers, a very mild spice. finish - dry, but soft and sweet, followed by an increase in smoke, aswell as the sense of a very salty, smoked meat, with a long finish. upon smelling this, i was abit wary of my 1st taste of this, and imagined myself choking up, but it is pleasantly smooth, and really is moreish. i'd recommend to anyone looking to try their first islay. this will be a continually stocked bottle i think. imagine a drop of water would open it up abit more but im yet to try, as my 1st dram was so complex and quite truthfully beautiful. i think it is an aquired taste though, and you either love it or hate it, but after my 1st sip, i feel like spreading this gem around hither and yon, but ill be keeping it mostly to myself i think.does not get much better than this, superb.it is wonderful. can smell the sea salted bogs which makes it unmatchable, in its own class. once you have some you get hooked for that aromatic sensation of the ocean and the bogs. entirely its own animal and should be given a latin species name!my favourite whisky. smokey & smooth. it’s my go to!

column4: A 'blend of Caribbean Rum, fine spirits and real coconut' producing a great coconut rum liqueur. Perfect for cocktails and tiki drinks.
column5: absolutely amazing! easy to drink over ice or with a mixer!best coconut rum i've ever had, hands down.better than malibu. too easy to drink.this stuff is so nice you pay more than malibu but it's much better.basically malibu but less sickly sweet

column4: Martini Rosso is claimed to be the world's first vermouth. The distinctive colour is produced by the addition of caramel, which also tempers the bittersweet effect of the 50+ herbs and spices used in production.
column5: absolutely horrific, could not drinkyes and it stinks. it has a horrible taste. not good for manhatansamazing with ice and soda waterlush caramel and spice. one of the more discerning martinis shall we say. winner every time and place or mood.good

column4: Oban Little Bay is married in the smallest casks available at the distillery, 200-litre ex-bourbon barrels. This has resulted in a rich whisky with notes of stone fruit, spice and honey. PRODUCER'S TASTING NOTES Appearance: Rich antique gold. Nose: Oily, waxy and nutty, balanced by ripe orchard fruits. Notes of almond fruit cake on denser Christmas pudding, with cereal and orange behind. Body: Medium to rich. Good viscosity. Palate: The comforting chewiness of rich fruit-bread, hints of orange zest and clove, growing drier, still minty, with crisp green apple. Finish: In a word, long. Quite syrupy at first, then drying, with elegant coating tannins rich in dark chocolate character.
column5: smooth as silk, excellenton the nose, lots of honey, sherry, orange and oatmeal. taste, arrival is overwhelmingly sweet, honey, peaches, raisins. the development instantly turns dry and spicy, black pepper, peat notes (enough to give it a 2/5 in the tasting notes i’d say), sherry, and lemongrass. finish is long, dry, and slightly peaty. a few drops of water does this malt wonders. 85/100 imo.bought on sale for $40 and worth every penny. i disagree with the reported "0" smoke. this has a light peat smoke element which is far from overwhelming yet present indeed. sweet, rich, peppery, and a steal at $40. going to buy another bottle for safe keeping at this price.i love it! so smooth.excellent!fantastic great house warming or party gift. or just something to have at homedelightful!full body. very fruity with a long finish. i just love it!!!this is a delightful find, and especially great for the price, i've found it at, which is half of what's listed here. very warm with fruity/bready sweetness, and definitely peppery on the end. clearly won't replace the sterling oban 14 on your shelf, but the price alone makes it worth having a bottle in your collection.i couldn't find my favourite glen morangie at duty free so took a chance on this and absolutely love it!!great dram forget the 12 or 14 and go blendedcomplex and very enjoyable!excellent!! lives up to the reviews i’ve read!great taste very smooth with good fruit nose.easy one of the best i have ever tasted just got it here in the states.i honestly was disappointed with this one, too peppery for my tastes. i get some fruit on the backend, but all in all i would not buy againhas unseated lagavulin as my go to brew.smooth!!!!! very nice.smooth and rich! comes with a reasonable price. one of my favourites.excellentoban nailed this nas whisky. fruity nutty and spicy yet mellow without the young whisky varnish flavor that haunts many nas scotches. my local store has it on sale for $35! going to buy 10 more at that price!

column4: Urban Moonshine’s hand-crafted Digestive Bitters are a well balanced, aromatic, non-laxative update to traditional bitters formulas. These original digestive bitters are certified organic and handcrafted to please everyone. Why take bitters?
column5: This has saved me from going to a gastro specialist. I am so happy to have found this product. I was bloating like I was seven months pregnant after almost everything I ate. I tried elimination diet, and cut out dairy and soy, which helped, but still have problems with grains, vegetables and other foods like berries. It's crazy. So now I just take this with a little water with almost every meal, and it has made eating bearable again! Cut down the problem by 80% and I just feel better when I take it. It helps right away. I highly recommend trying it. Good Luck! I made the mistake of not re-ordering when running out. My belly has calmed down significantly since my refill arrived. This is the most amazing product! If you ever get an upset tummy, take half a dropper and the positive effect is basically immediate. I HIGHLY recommend this as a staple in your house or your purse (that is where you will find my bottle)! My doctor recommended these because I wanted something natural. They have a strong earthy flavor, but I got use to it. I use a dropper full in an 8oz glass of water and drink it 1st thing in the morning. It helps with bloating and nausea. They work better than the DGL chews I ordered. I highly recommend it to anyone with digestive issues. If I am having a gut attack from food I take Swedish bitters and it will take the attack away It has saved me trips to the emergency room many times I have leaky gut It’s a gut disease They say 80% of the worlds population has it but they just don’t know it After two years of bloating and pain from small amounts of food I am pleased with these bitters. I have been using a half dropper twice a day. The taste is not as horrid as other reviews- strong? yes but that's the purpose. I think going back to what worked before pharmaceuticals took over the world is a good thing. This is my second bottle of digestive bitters. I have Crohn’s and have had lots of digestive issues. I love these bitterness in some H2O and a little gin. 😊 it’s a perfect stomach soother before dinner. This is one of the only things that has helped my acid reflux and stomach issues. It works quickly and helps with digestion and bloating. The taste is pretty strong at first but it is not terrible. I got use to it pretty quickly. I was looking for an herbal alternative to taking Prilosec and this has completely solved my indigestion/slow digestion problem. Great product!

column4: California- American India Pale Ale (IPA)- 6.2% ABV. This is Lagunitas' unique version of an ancient style. It is made with 43 different hops and 65 various malts. This IPA is full of flavor with notes of spice, roasted malts, caramel, and citrus fruit.
column5: I would say if you have never had an IPA or want to try one but don't like a lot of others, that this is the IPA for you. It's crisps and goes down well with not a lot of hops so you are still able to get that "IPA taste" without it being to hoppy like others. Great hoppy IPA My go-to beer for the last few years All these years later....& still one of the best IPA’s ever created! Keep it up! We tap keg each year on Thanksgiving after touch football. This IPA was outstanding. It went too fast. Must buy for cool crisp days with good friends and family. So easy to order, walk in and get. Very good IPA, but there are many these days and this is a bit pricey in the 6pk. Need a 12pk to hit that 14 price range This is such a well balanced beer. Great flavor and not too strong. Tastes great in the mouth, My favorite IPA by far. Even my wife likes it. If you can only choose one IPA, this should be your choice. I have been brewing beer for over 20 years and have tasted over 200 IPA's. Much more flavorful than Stone, no offense to the other reviewers, but very few beers deserve 5 stars. This is a decent IPA with a nice balance of hops and malt, decent aroma, and dry finish. It's a 3.5 star, but since half stars are not an option on TWM's website, I am giving it 3 to balance out the other reviewer's 5. A really memorable (i.e. 5 star) beer has an aroma and taste that you remember after you finish drinking it, and you look forward to having it again. Try this head to head with a Dogfish Head 90 or Stone's Ruin Ten and I think you'll get the idea... I love IPAs, but Maximus is a little too heavy for me. This is perfect!

column4: A delicious creamy Blanco rum from popular Venezuelan producer Pampero. By law, Venezuelan rum must be aged for a minimum of two years, meaning this is smoother and more characterful than standard white rums.
A cracking Venezuelan añejo, popular in style bars as either a sipping rum or a highly versatile top-quality cocktail ingredient.
column5: i love the taste and no hangover!! wonderful stuff, sweet yes but definately not sickly. a lovely vanilla/honey/oak aroma and taste with some depth, this is great for both drinking neat (it goes down very easily indeed) or as a mixer base. one of the sweetest cheap rums i've tasted. at this price you cannot expect too much and nothing particularly aged either but this is surprisingly smooth & sweet. it's pretty one dimensional stuff - don't go looking for "hints of cigar-box" here. it's just nice, sweet, golden rum. you can mostly definitely enjoy this neat because it's so smooth. so for a dime under 20 squids you cannot go wrong if you like your rums sweet'n'smooth. this is probably the most widely consumed rum in venezuela. it is enormously popular and rightly so. it has great depth of flavour and sweetness that one associates with the south american palate. super to mix with coca cola, ice and lemon for a great cuba libre.

column4: US Virgin Islands- Bring a taste of the tropics to your favorite mixers. A premium blend of refreshing tropical coconut with light, crisp Puerto Rican rum. Mix with cola or add to any number of your favorite cocktails for a tropical twist.
column5: Have been enjoying for years. Best just on the rocks. This unique rum is a cut above for any tropical drink that uses rum.

column4: US Virgin Islands- Premium rum made with a distinctively tropical passion fruit flavor. When mixed with your favorite juice, it creates wildly colorful cocktails that are delicious and easy to drink.US Virgin Islands- Premium rum made with a distinctively tropical passion fruit flavor. When mixed with your favorite juice, it creates wildly colorful cocktails that are delicious and easy to drink.
column5: I love this drink very much and combined with orange juice is the maximum I was looking for a clear Rum that I could enjoy and while in Total Wine I happened to run in the Parrot Bay Passion Fruit Rum. It makes a delicious drink when paired with Lipton Mixed Berry Green Tea. Of course I add a slice of lime to make it even better.

column4: "Bring a taste of the tropics to your favorite mixers. A premium blend of strawberry flavors with light, crisp Puerto Rican rum." -Producer

The Bitter Truth Peach Bitters are a contemporary interpretation of a classic style of bitters once popular in the first golden age the cocktail. Although peach bitters never reached the popularity of orange bitters, they were one of the wider used bitters. The Bitter Truth Peach Bitters are fresh and fruity with intense peach notes, backed up by a seducing hint of almonds. A combination of fresh peach aroma and subtle spicy flavors adds an exquisite fruitiness to cocktails and long drinks. They work well with clear and aged spirits such as cognac and bourbon whiskey. A Mint Julep will be lifted to new heights. Tasting Notes: Delicate peach notes, balanced with hints of almonds and backed up with spices and balanced bitter nuances. Fruity with a faint almond bitterness from the pits. The natural aroma of fresh peaches dominates while it is completed by fresh citrus and unobtrusive spice flavors. The finish tails off with a herbaceous, nutty note, leaving more fizzy peach to linger.
column5: December 13, 2014 at 11:30 pm...a bar in Helsinki, Finland. I sat on a classy leather sofa, mesmerized as across the room, one of the pre-eminent mixologists in the country, Jaakko, shuffled through the creation of four masterpieces at one time. His hands were like those of a conductor, flowing back and forth, adding liquor, fruit, mixers and more...all seemingly at once. A dropper would fall into a drink and he would taste the creation to confirm that the appropriate mix of melted ice water and booze would come together in exactly the right way. Anyway...I digress. I love an Old Fashioned. I love multiple Old Fashioneds, even as I remain unsure whether putting an S at the end is appropriate grammar. Yet it seems that every time I'm in a bar, my Old Fashioned tastes different. Until Jaakko's Old Fashioned, that is. I had been to this place a number of times before and truly, every drink they made seemed like a masterpiece of sorts. But the Old Fashioned was seriously out of this world and it was always perfect. During this most recent visit after that first sweet sip of genius, I decided I had to go engage Jaakko and learn how he made my favorite drink. So I did. I walked up to the bar, waited until he was finished his current order and introduced myself. I told him that his Old Fashioned was the best I've ever had and I was hoping he would enlighten me as to the how and the why. HIs response? Well...I learned that Jaakko's favorite drink was also an Old Fashioned and immediately, I understood the relevance. He then provided me with TWO key tips: Tip ONE: Jaakko said that all too often, people order their Old Fashioned with Makers Mark bourbon. He felt that using Knob Creek was a much better fit. He said it has a slightly sweeter and spicier taste which goes well with the bitters...that brings me to the 2nd tip. Tip TWO: Two kinds of bitters. Jaakko makes his Old Fashioned with regular old Angostura bitters BUT ALSO with a few dashes of Peach bitters. Boom. That's what I was looking for. I thanked him, told him I would see him again and returned to my sofa seat, opened my Amazon app and immediately purchased these Peach bitters to be waiting for me when I got home five days later. On my first night home, I bought a bottle of Knob Creek and recreated Jaakko's Old Fashioned. I didn't have the perfect ice, of course, and I wasn't in the cold yet dark warmth of a Helsinki bar during winter but it was the best I've ever made and that is good enough. Buy these bitters. Buy these bitters. I really should get back to work. I love Fee Brothers products. I use a lot of them for various recipes and concoctions throughout the year. The peach bitters are used primarily for a peach sangria that I make from scratch each summer when the peaches are in abundance. The bitters add just the right amount of kick that would be sorely lacking had it not been included. Anything by Fee Brothers is worth the investment. I've tried these bitters in two drinks so far and it has been a great addition to both. The peach flavor comes through perfectly -- it's a natural-tasting flavor, not artificial at all. The first thing that strikes you might be the price. It may be the most expensive four ounces of liquid in my house right now, but a little bit goes a long, long way. Bitter has made an intense comeback onto the craft-cocktail scene at bars and restaurants, and amazon is making it super easy to create your own craft cocktail at home by offering almost the entire Fee Brothers line of bitters. Fee Brothers has always been our bitter manufacturer of choice and we were super excited to see amazon offering it at such an amazing price. This flavor, Peach, has been pushed to the front of the line at our bar since we have been playing around with some fun southern cocktails... is there anything more southern than a Georgia Peach? A+ on Value, Shipping and Quality. Good Ice, a little white wine, couple shakes of bitters and soda water - what a yummy drink. The bitters jazzes up an otherwise ordinary drink. And try the Plum Bitters too - they are great! If you make your own iced tea, this (plus a pinch of citric acid) is just the thing to get that slightly tart peach flavoring that Snapple does so well. This, and the "old fashioned" bitters, are my favorite flavorings for iced tea. For a change we like to use these Peach Bitters and their Black Walnut Bitters together in our Manhattans. So good!

column4: The bitter housewife cardamom bitters adds balance to sweet drinks. These surprisingly savory bitters lead a duplicitous life. Adds depth and balance to sweeter drinks based on apple, pear, or orange blending right in with the smoky characteristics of an anejo tequila or scotch. However our favorite use for the bitter housewife cardamom bitters is in a gin collins sweetened with rosemary syrup. All natural, alcohol base, made in Portland.
column5: Not only for cocktails - great for cooking (rice pudding, sauces, in syrups! I do wish the bottles accommodated a dasher top. Nicely flavored tired of them bitters for your craft cocktail recipes. Would buy again interesting flavor, high quality Been getting into gin lately. If you haven't tried Dry Fly Gin then you must! These grapefruit bitters go so well with many gin drinks. If you are building out your bar collection I recommend the Bitter Housewife bitters. Very nice orange flavor. Great addition to an Old Fashioned. If you're looking for the best orange bitters, I find Fee Brothers Gin Barrel Aged Orange Bitters to be the best.

column4: Rather more special than the famous Bristol Cream, this is a super-luxurious Pedro Ximenez sherry from Harvey's, comprised of solera-aged sherry over 30 years old. Incredibly rich, sweet and unctuous. Winner of a Gold Medal at the International Wine Challenge 2010 and a Bronze at the Decanter World Wine Awards
column5: Lovely deep burnt cinder taste - unique a cut above the rest...a wonderful sherry of all time in this world of wines...brilliant!!...i will score this 9.5/10

column4: Argh! Avast ye! Fer what ye might be a wantin’ in yer grog The Bitter Truth pimento be all yer need. The color o’ a treasure chest and the smell o’ home – Jamaica – yer won’t be wastin’ this on yer parrot. Pimento, or Allspice fer ye land lubbers, be a berry that when dried ‘ll taste like cinnamon, clove and nut- meg. All o’ which go together like a sea shanty and a drunken sailor with the heady Jamaican rum, argh! Try it an’ yer’ll find a Jacobs Ladder o’ flavour from clove te cinnamon, te nutmeg, te star anis w’ a finish o’ hot smoked maple syrup and dry cardamom and clove ah-gain. Stick it w’ some rum in yer black jack and yer powder monkey’s ‘ll be avast swingin’ on the poopdeck all night. Arrrrgh! The Bitter Truth Pimento Dram is based on selected pimento/allspice (also called Jamaica pepper) and the finest Jamaican rum. English explorers coined the term allspice because the berry seemed to embody the flavors of cinnamon, nutmeg and clove all at once. On the Caribbean island of Jamaica, this distinctive aromatic liqueur has been produced for generations by macerating allspice in rum. Tasting Notes: Sweet, spicy and very intense. Clove initially presents itself in the foreground, fading into the pure flavors of cinnamon, nutmeg and pepper which linger on the tongue.
column5: Great tiki ingredient! Bought it to make Three Dots and a Dash.

column4: Guinness' flavour derives from malted barley and roasted unmalted barley, a relatively modern development, not becoming part of the grist until the mid-20th century. For many years, a portion of aged brew was blended with freshly brewed beer to give a sharp lactic acidflavour. Although Guinness's palate still features a characteristic "tang", the company has refused to confirm whether this type of blending still occurs. The draught beer's thick, creamy head comes from mixing the beer with nitrogen and carbon dioxide.[6]
column5: drank while living in england for over 2 years. it is so great; refreshing and a great summer drink!

column4: A limited edition fruit cup from Pimm's, combining their knowledge of fruity spirits with a love of blackberry and elderflower to produce a fantastic summery drink. Serve over ice, topped up with twice as much lemonade as Pimm's.

column4: The company moved its headquarters to London at the beginning of the Anglo-Irish Trade War in 1932. In 1997, Guinness Plc merged with Grand Metropolitan to form the multinational alcoholic-drinks producer Diageo plc, based out of London.

column5: loved the hint of mint we served it with lots of ice fresh strawberries and mint. went down a storm with everyone.refreshing served with lemonade, garnished with cucumber, orange, lemon and fresh strawberries and very drinkable on a summers day alongside a bbq. a drink everybody will enjoy.

column4: A beer that straddles between the mainstream Pale Lager and Pilsner. Not all beers that call themselves Premium Lager are, but those that are will typically have a deep gold to light bronze colour, and distinct influence of malt and hops. They should be free of adjuncts and will have a softer carbonation than Pale Lager or Classic German Pilsner. IBUs will typically range in the 20’s, and lagering times will typically be 4-6 weeks, more in line with what pilsners have. Overall accent will be malty-to-balanced, alcohol in a slightly tighter range than either Pale Lager or Pilsner (4.5-5.5%). Most often the product of a microbrewery or brewpub, but macrobreweries can make this style if they jack up the hops a bit and make it all-malt.
Gocce di Favola is a crisp, fresh and fruity Prosecco with notes of apples and pears. This is a refreshing aperitif sparkling wine.
column5: very nice and easy to drinkdescription is exactly what it is a lovely drink

one of the best i've ever tried. this is a delight my husband and i will savor and not share.having tasted this rum for the first time recently , it was a case of buy buy buy! by far the best rum on the marketstunning! heaven in a bottlethis was the tastiest rum in my price range by a mile! this on the rocks is pure heaven. hints of vanilla, possibly pineapple, coconut, light very faint spice. as smooth as silk...amazing, beautifully presented and wonderfully complex a great rum one to sip and enjoyone of the best rums i ever had love the bottlethe bestthis is a great rum, tastes amazing with a nice cigar on a cold winters night. however for the money i feel the 23 is probably a better buy as it will satisfy on more occasions and is probably a bit easier to drinkthe absolute benchmark for me. considerably better than the fantastic '23', this is my 'house' favourite. only bettered below 300 pounds by ron centenario 25 (similar price) or 30 if you feel flush.i've always been a fan of the 23yr old rz, however, my life has now changed since experiencing the xo. i now have a stock of over 20 bottles in my house and i only drink xo. even if guests visit my house, i refuse to give them anything but xo. they leave my house extremely pleased with my determination. i thank you xo, i love you xo.got this as a present for doing a good deed. never heard of it. to say i am impressed is an understatement. i normally spend "good" money on scotch and bourbon... this is now on my "good" list. risk/enjoy/live... cheers.i am a premium bourbon drinker and have tried for years to find a rum that delivered the level of flavor and complexity as some of my favorite bourbons. my years of search are over. zacapa xo solera is really something special. it has a deep, rich copper hue. i drink it neat. this rum is very smooth with next to no burn. very enjoyable.

Pour Smirnoff Ice over a tall glass of ice, garnish with a lime or lemon wedge. On a hot day this will quench your ADULT thirst. Enjoy.

column4:
Whether you sip it on the rocks or with soda and a twist, Smirnoff No. 21 is the perfect addition to a cocktail party. Our award-winning, 80 proof vodka has robust flavor with a dry finish for ultimate smoothness and clarity. 

Triple distilled and 10 times filtered, our vodka traditionally can be taken alone or added to your favorite mixed drink. Simply mix with ginger beer and lime juice for a classic Moscow Mule.

Founded in 1864, the Smirnoff brand traveled from Russia to the rest of the world due to our award-winning quality and smooth liquid. We pride ourselves on bringing our famous beverage to connoisseurs and newcomers alike, assuring the consistently great taste and quality expected from our traditionally distilled vodka. Please drink responsibly.
